basics.name: Zichen Wang
basics.label: PhD candidate/Bioinformatician/Data Scientist
basics.summary: Zichen Wang is a PhD candidate in biomedical informatics, with intensive experiences in systems pharmacology, transcriptomics and sequencing data analysis. I have also been actively applying machine learning methods in my research. I am also interested and experienced in interactive data visualization and web development.

work.company: Ma'ayan lab at Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai
work.summary: The Ma'ayan Laboratory develops computational and mathematical methods to study the complexity of regulatory networks in mammalian cells.
highlights: Proved the existence of research focus bias by modeling the longitudinal discovery process of protein-protein interaction network from low-content studies.
Developed a machine learning multi-label classification model to predict drug side effects using features extracted from transcriptomic response profiles and chemical structures.
Applied crowd-sourcing approach to curate gene expression data from public repository and created web portal for the visualization and query of the dataset.

education.institution: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai
education.area: Biomedical Science, Genetic and Genomic Sciences
courses: Computer Programing in System Biology & Bioinformatics

publications.name: Drug Induced Adverse Events Prediction with the LINCS L1000 Data
publications.summary: Adverse Drug Reactions (ADRs) are a central consideration during drug development. Here we present a machine learning classifier to prioritize ADRs for approved drugs and pre-clinical small-molecule compounds by combining chemical structure (CS) and gene expression (GE) features. The GE data is from the Library of Integrated Network-based Cellular Signatures (LINCS) L1000 dataset that measured changes in GE before and after treatment of human cells with over 20,000 small molecule compounds including most of the FDA-approved drugs. Using various ben-chmarking methods, we show that the integration of GE data with the CS of the drugs can significantly improve the predictability of ADRs. Moreover, transforming GE features to enrichment vectors of biological terms further improves the predictive capability of the classifiers. The most predictive biological-term features can assist in understanding the drug mechanisms of action. Finally, we applied the classifier to all >20,000 small molecules profiled, and developed a web portal for browsing and searching predictive small-molecule/ADR connections.

publications.name: Dynamics of the discovery process of protein-protein interactions from low content studies
publications.summary: We analyzed the longitudinal discovery process of literature-based mammalian and yeast PPINs to observe that these networks are discovered non-uniformly. The pattern of discovery is related to a theoretical concept proposed by Kauffman called “expanding the adjacent possible”. We introduce a network discovery model which explicitly includes the space of possibilities in the form of a true underlying PPIN.
